metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Respondents (Title Suit No. 16 of 1944)

facts.text: Satyananda, last male owner, died unmarried in 1902-1903; succeeded by mother Haripriya who lived till 1942.
Haripriya sold portion of property in 1916 to Indumati, daughter of Dharanidhar Misra.
Suit No. 31 of 1917 filed by Natabar and Janardan (agnates of Lokenath) challenging alienation; decreed on August 31, 1918, as without legal necessity.
Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act II of 1929 passed, elevating sister's son in Mitakshara succession.

Plaintiffs-respondents (Nimai Charan Misra, Lakshminarayan Misra, Baikuntha Pati) filed Title Suit No. 16 of 1944 for declaration of title and possession, claiming as sons of daughters of Lokenath (half-sister of Satyananda via first wife Satyabhama).
Pedigree by plaintiffs: Sankarsan > Balaram > Bhubana > Baidyanath > Raghunath > Purushottam > Satyabhama (1st wife of Lokenath) > daughters Ahalya, Brindabati, Malabati > sons including plaintiffs.
Defendants-appellant claimed Ahalya and Malabati as daughters of Baidyanath Misra (father of Haripriya), not Lokenath.
Appellant's pedigree: Baidyanath Misra > Haripriya (m. Lokenath) > Satyananda; Ahalya, Malabati daughters of Baidyanath.

Ex. 1: Petition dated November 2, 1917 by Satyabadi (for self and brothers Baikuntha, Dasarath) in Suit No. 31/1917, containing pedigree showing Ahalya etc. as daughters of Lokenath; filed Nov 5, rejected Nov 27.
Subordinate Judge Sambalpur decreed suit on Jan 31, 1946, holding plaintiffs sons of Lokenath's daughters.
Orissa High Court affirmed on March 9, 1951, except modifying damages; relied on Ex.1 under s.32(5) and oral evidence under s.50.
Oral evidence: Janardan Misra (PW2, age 62), Sushila Misrani (PW3, age 43), Dharanidhar Misra (PW4, age 96) testified to attending marriages and ceremonies treating parties as related via Lokenath.

legal_issues.text: Admissibility of Ex.1 (pedigree petition from 1917) under s.32 sub-s.5 of Evidence Act.
Admissibility of oral testimony of Janardan Misra, Sushila Misrani, Dharanidhar Misra under s.50 of Evidence Act as opinion expressed by conduct.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pedigree incorrect; Ahalya and Malabati daughters of Baidyanath Misra, not Lokenath; plaintiffs not preferential heirs.
Ex.1 not admissible under s.32(5) as not ante litem motam (dispute arose in 1917 suit), Satyabadi lacked special knowledge independently, joint statement with living persons.
Oral evidence of PWs 2,3,4 inadmissible under s.50 as hearsay, not opinion by conduct of persons with special knowledge; no direct proof.

respondent_arguments.text: Plaintiffs are sons of daughters of Lokenath by first wife Satyabhama (half-sister of Satyananda), entitled under 1929 Act and Privy Council in Sahodra.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act 1929; Mst. Sahodra v. Ram Babu

respondent_arguments.text: Janardan's evidence direct proof of facts seen (attendances at marriages), or admissible under s.50.

court_reasoning.text: s.50 requires court to form opinion on relationship; opinion by conduct of person with special means of knowledge is relevant; proved as direct evidence per s.60; not mere hearsay or reputation without conduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Janardan and Dharanidhar had special knowledge (related/neighbours, attended ceremonies as relatives); their attendance expresses belief in relationship.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence of Janardan (saw marriages of Malabati as Lokenath's daughter, her daughters, plaintiffs' Upanayan) and Dharanidhar (attendances) admissible under s.50 as conduct expressing opinion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not casual; invited as relations, reasonable inference of belief.

court_reasoning.text: s.32(5) conditions: declarant dead (Satyabadi), relates to relationship, special knowledge (son of Ahalya, admitted mother), ante litem motam (no dispute on Lokenath-daughters relation in 1917 suit).
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1917 suit on alienation necessity; no inter se reversioner title issue; nearest reversioner party.

court_reasoning.text: Special knowledge for Satyabadi independently proved by oral evidence; Ex.1 statements his as signer.
Weight of evidence for lower courts; affirms findings.

holdings.text: Oral evidence of Janardan Misra and Dharanidhar Misra admissible under s.50 Evidence Act as opinion expressed by conduct of persons with special knowledge.
Ex.1 admissible under s.32(5) Evidence Act; all conditions fulfilled, ante litem motam.
Privy Council in Sahodra binds; half-sister entitled under 1929 Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Half-sister entitled to 1929 Act benefit; settled law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chandu Lal Agarwala v. Khalilar Rahman
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains s.50: conduct proves opinion if tenor implies inner belief.
s.50 not for mere general reputation without conduct.
Family member can give hearsay-based independent opinion by conduct.
s.50 exceptional proof; conduct provable by others.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chandra Nath Roy v. Nilamadhab Bhattacharjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Joint statement treated as of dead person if signed by dead.
s.32(5) not for interested denials in litigation.
Special knowledge needs independent proof; here provided.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of pedigree statement and opinion by conduct on relationship.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law of Inheritance (Amendment) Act, 1929
statutes_cited.relevance: Elevated sister's son above agnates; applied to half-sister.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court and trial court findings on pedigree via admissible evidence under ss.32(5) and 50 Evidence Act; affirmed decree for plaintiffs-respondents subject to High Court's modification on damages.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of title and possession to plaintiffs-respondents; damages as modified.

key_quotes.text: "It is only opinion as expressed by conduct which is made relevant. This is how the conduct comes in."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scope of s.50 Evidence Act.

key_quotes.text: "Opinion means something more than mere retailing of gossip or of hearsay; it means judgment or belief."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Four conditions must be fulfilled for the application of sub-s.(5) of s.32: declarant dead, relates to relationship, special knowledge, ante litem motam."
key_quotes.speaker: court
